results.title: Rikki-tikki-tavi
results.creator_credit: Chuck Jones and Chuck Jones Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Kipling classic from ‘The jungle books’”.
An animated version of Rudyard Kipling’s tale of a mongoose who is saved from a storm by a boy and his parents, and then becomes the family’s defender against the dreaded cobras that roam the compound. Narrated by Orson Welles. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: The White seal
results.creator_credit: Chuck Jones and Chuck Jones Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Kipling classic from ‘The jungle books’”.
Based on a tale in Kipling’s “The Jungle Book”, this exciting animated film follows the exploits of Kotick, the white seal, as he struggles to survive and save his friends from seal hunters in the Bering Sea. Narrated by Roddy McDowall to music from Beethoven’s Sixth Symphony. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: Mowgli's brothers
results.creator_credit: Chuck Jones, Chuck Jones Enterprises and Xerox Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Kipling classic from ‘The jungle books’”.
Animated version of Kipling’s classic tale of a boy rescued and raised by wolves in the jungles of India comes alive in this film about love, justice and loyalty. Features the voices of Roddy McDowall and June Foray. Teacher’s notes accompany the video. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

group_works.title: Capitalism
group_works.creator_credit: Yves Gerard Issembert, Sidney Platt and National Geographic Society

results.title: Capitalism
results.creator_credit: Yves Gerard Issembert, Sidney Platt and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Capitalism, socialism, communism”.
A general introduction to capitalist economies. The video traces the development of the market economy in late 17th Century Britain, where colonial expansion and the beginning of industrialisation saw the rise of the merchant and labouring classes. The video offers an introduction to the “laissez-faire” economic theories of Adam Smith which argue for a completely deregulated market with no government intervention. The experience of the Great Depression, however, is highlighted to indicate the limits to deregulation and to explore the tension in capitalist societies between satisfying the needs of the market and the needs of human beings.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Yves Gerard Issembert, Sidney Platt and National Geographic Society

results.title: Keeping the old game alive
results.creator_credit: Douglas Kiefer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “War”.
Every autumn in central Europe, the combined forces of fifteen member countries of NATO meet to conduct their war games - the most elaborate dress rehersal for World War III. Dyer examines some of the technically sophisticated conventional weaponry used by modern armies and outlines the nightmarish effects of chemical weapons on unprotected civilians.

results.title: Deadly game of nations
results.creator_credit: Paul Cowan, Bill Brind, John Kramer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “War”.
All through history, wars have been linked to feelings of nationalism. There is hardly any country in the world that did not establish iself by means of wars. In this film Gwynne Dyer explors some of the reasons why pople, and governments acting on their behalf, feel the need to keep armies and fight wars. It focuses on Israel’s struggle for a secure place amongst the Arab nations of the Middle East, and on the so far unsuccessful attempts of the Palestinians to create a nation of their own.

results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “War”.
(War series 3) This video is about professional soldiers - the career officers in every country who devote their lives to maintaining military organizations and nurturing the attitides that go with them.

results.title: Goodbye war
results.creator_credit: Donna Dudinsky, Barbara Sears, Judith Merritt and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “War”.
For centuries the international system of states has settled questions of power, territory, national pride and sovereignty with military force. At any given time there are about twenty wars being waged in the international neighbourhood, and in all of them, the people have a particular goal they want to achieve, a goal which they believe outweighs the cost of war. Dyer looks at a number of recent examples. He also examines the efforts of citizens’ peace movements in Europe, in the USA and in the Soviet Union. He suggests that we must find an alternative to war if the planet is to survive.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donna Dudinsky, Barbara Sears, Judith Merritt and National Film Board of Canada
